hint.text: The latent heat of water is 2256 \(\frac {J}{g}\). This means for 1 g of water \(\Delta\;Q = 2256 J\).

solution.text:
From the first law, we know that:
\(\Delta U = \Delta Q - P \Delta V\)
\(\Delta Q = 2256 J\)
\(P \Delta V = P \times (V_g - V_l) = _{k}_ \times 10^5 \times (_{{trunc(Decimal(1671*1.013/k),2)}}_ - 1) \times 10^{-6} = _{{trunc(Decimal(k * 0.1 * ((1671*1.013/k) - 1)),3)}}_\)
\(\implies \Delta U = 2256 - _{{trunc(Decimal(k * 0.1 * ((1671*1.013/k) - 1)),3)}}_\)
\(\implies \Delta U = _{{trunc(Decimal(2256 - (k * 0.1 * ((1671*1.013/k) - 1))),3)}}_ \;J\)

content.text: What is the change in internal energy for 1 gram of water to go from liquid to vapour phase at pressure of _{k}_ bar. Note that the measured latent heat of water is 2256 \(\frac {J}{g}\). At the given pressure, 1 g of water has a volume \(1 \;cm^3\) in liquid phase and \(_{{trunc(Decimal(1671*1.013/k),2)}}_ \;cm^3\) in vapour phase.
